The most common problems with rental properties were found to be pests; doors or windows that did not close property; peeling paint or tiles coming off; leaks or flooding; and persistent mould. 
One Twitter user ticked off the list and myriad other problems. â€œShall I continue,â€ she concluded . â€œThatâ€™s just one house.â€ 
Surveyed tenants were quoted in the Choice report talking about rental properties with significant, in some cases structural, issues that were not being addressed by landlords. 
One spoke of living in a house with â€œmajor plumbing issuesâ€: â€œPlumber admitted he was close to giving up and [said] the house would be condemned with the sewage not working â€“ a.k.a. all over the yard and laundry.â€ 
Another lived in a house with a leaking roof that was â€œtaking ages for them to repairâ€. 
That was still an improvement on the experience of another interviewee, who said the roof had â€œcaved in from water damageâ€, while the boards of the propertyâ€™s deck were â€œso old theyâ€™re going to snapâ€. 
One former tenant would have probably felt validated when â€œthe dwelling was deemed unfit for living by the councilâ€. 
The survey found fear of retribution was common among tenants, particularly given the short supply of housing. Eighty-three per cent of renters were without a fixed-term lease and faced â€œconstant insecurityâ€, Choice said. 
â€œConstantly worried that if I make a complaint we wonâ€™t be offered to rent again,â€ wrote one. â€œWe would not be able to afford to move let alone afford new rent.â€ 
Another tenant reported being told, upon signing a lease, that the house would be left as it was, â€œotherwise the rent would be put upâ€. 
One was given notice to leave a property that had been home for five years after requesting some maintenance work be done, including to fix a bathroom that flooded during rain. 
â€œThe owner said it wasnâ€™t worth his while to have tenants â€¦ He gave me plenty of notice and got very angry when I secured a new rental property within days of getting his notice, he told me I couldnâ€™t leave now. But bad luck for him as the notice to leave said I had to be out by a certain date, I got out well before.â€ 
Another said similar: â€œI was given a notice to leave after landlord had two minor costs for maintenance. Said he would rather have no tenants.â€ 
Choice is calling on people to share their experiences using #RentInOz so that it can better campaign for tenantsâ€™ rights.
